title: Auto deburr on some string methods
body:
When calling some string methods all diacritics are stripped (or in fact changed to their latin counterpart - exactly the behaviour of deburr method):
```javascript
_.camelCase('zażółć gęślą jaźń') // zazolcGeslaJazn
```
It applies also to à ä æ å ā ö ø ë.

I found following methods suffer from that:
- camelCase
- kebabCase
- lowerCase
- snakeCase
- startCase
- upperCase

Following methods do not have that behaviour and work correctly:
- capitalize
- lowerFirst
- toLower
- toUpper
- upperFirst

I did not check any other methods.

EDIT: I found that all above methods use `createCompounder` which explicitly calls `deburr`. Is it the intended behaviour? It seems that in case of changing case [sic!] it is not needed for e.g. capitalize works perfect without removing diacritics.

title: bindAll is missing from master
body: I'm wondering why the source code for `_.bindAll` is missing from master.

title: fp.set doesn't work
Allow _.inRange() to be inclusive
body:
Currently, `_.inRange()` is not inclusive to `end`. Then it acts like `start <= value < end`. It is bad for some reasons, like when you need check if value is inside some percentage. For instance:

* If `x` is range of 0% to 50% (_should not be inclusive_)
* If `x` is range 50% to 100% (_should be inclusive_)

In second case, currently we should do something like `_.inRange(x, 50, 100.1)`. But it sounds bad because it could allow the value 100.05 (_okay, it do not fit on this context, but could fix in context where exists more precision/decimals_).

**Solution:** create a 4th boolean parameter that turn this function inclusive to `end` parameter. It should avoid breaking changes and hacks like that.

title: _.clamp doesn't check lower vs. upper bounds
body: It seems to me that if we provide three arguments to `_.clamp`, we're specifying a range of numbers that it should be clamped to. In v4.17.4, incorrect results occur when `lower` is greater than `upper`. It seems to me that the clamp code could be made smarter, so that it recognizes which of the two range endpoints is lower. That way, the caller doesn't have to do additional logic to ensure that it's passing the lower endpoint first.

**Update:**
I found solution myself: https://github.com/lodash/lodash/wiki/FP-Guide#convert

title: assignIn, extend source type checking gone
body:
I've noticed in newer version of lodash
```
_.extend({}, 'abc');
=>
{ 0: 'a', 1: 'b', 2: 'c' }
```
In underscore and earlier versions of lodash, the extend function included the guard, `if (iterable && objectTypes[typeof iterable])` which prevented the object from being extended with a string; so, 

```
_.extend({}, 'abc');
=>
{}
```
Garbage in garbage out I guess, but this seemed like a useful guard to me.

Was this change intentional or do you consider this a regression?

title: Add async template feature
body: This creates an `async function`, allowing the use of `await` in tags.

title: Enhance _.cloneDeepWith() customizer
body:
Right now it's not possible to specify that a property shouldn't be cloned at all (or that it should be cloned as undefined). This is, because when returning "undefined", lodash takes over. And there is no way to tell lodash to omit a property from being cloned. 

**In my case, however, I want certain properties NOT to appear in the clone at all.** E.g. in our frontend code we use a lot of "private" properties that start with `$`. There are several cases where we need to deep clone the business objects with the private properties removed. Right now, what we're doing is using _.cloneDeep() and only afterwards are we able to iterate over the object once more in order to remove the unwanted properties. As we have rather large business models (of up to 10 MB in rare cases), this double iteration adds up in time, resulting in a lousy performance.

title: include hyphen in _.escapeRegExp
body:
Run the following on in your console:
```js
var regex = new RegExp('[' + _.escapeRegExp('!?.,:;(){}\[\]<>\-+=$%&#@*^"\'_|/\\') + ']')
```
Observe the error:

SyntaxError: invalid range in character class

This is because in a character set, or square brackets, a hyphen indicates a range, such as: 0-9

Yes, I could include the hyphen at the beginning of the character set.

_.throttle() on mouse events prevents event.offsetX/offsetY from working in Firefox
body:
It appears that, if you use `_.throttle()` or `_.debounce()` on mouse events in Firefox, it can sometimes prevent the event offsetX and offsetY parameters from working. Those properties sometimes contain '0' instead of the proper values.

I don't know if this is a Lodash issue or a Firefox issue,. but perhaps this should be dealt with in Lodash either way.

Here is a JSFiddle that reproduces the issue: https://jsfiddle.net/amoc1dqj/

When I scroll with my mousewheel when over the div labeled "Native", the JS console always shows the proper offsets. When I scroll the mousewheel over the div marked "Throttled", I sometimes get the proper offset, but sometimes I get zero. If I scroll fast with the mousewheel, the first event usually has the proper offset but later events do not.

I am using Firefox 53.0 64-bit official version by Mozilla on Linux (Debian Jessie AMD64)

Add first-class support for WHATWG URL objects?
body:
Any chance of adding specially cased first-class support for WHATWG URL objects for functions like `_.isEqual`, `_.isMatch`, etc.?
 - https://nodejs.org/docs/latest-v7.x/api/url.html#url_the_whatwg_url_api
 - https://url.spec.whatwg.org/
 - https://developer.mozilla.org/en/docs/Web/API/URL

The trouble is that these URL objects are, IMHO, essentially un-semantic in nature as they have prototypally inherited `get` property descriptors rather than owned properties.

Related issue, with utilizing `_.isEqual` and `_.isMatch`, both of which fail for these URL objects:
https://github.com/JamesMGreene/chai-deep-match/issues/2

title: _.rename
body:
Renames a key in an object.
```JavaScript
fp.rename('foo', 'bar', { foo: 'yo' }); // => { bar: 'yo' }
```
Also might be useful to have _.renameIn:
```
fp.renameIn('a.b', 'foo', 'bar', { a: { b: { foo: 'yo' } } }) // => { a: { b: { bar: 'yo' } } }

```

Such behaviour disappears if I do `import debounce from 'loadash/debounce`

title: _.get(obj, [])
body:
why on earth does that not return obj? Seems very illogical to me.

Reason:

the equation
```js
_.get(_.get(obj, arr.slice(0,-k)), arr.slice(-k)) === _.get(obj, arr)
```
in the current implementation is `true` for `1 <= k <= arr.length-1`

if `_.get(obj, [])` were properly defined, it would be true for `1 <= k <= arr.length`

A good definition is a definition making "nice laws" as the above as universally true as possible.

Think of the power law as an analogue.

Not defining `_.get(obj, []) = obj` is as illogical as not defining that a number to the power of zero is one.

title: does Object : commonKeys exists ?
import statements contain `.js` extension?
body:
First up - love love love love this project and I want to thank you personally for the ES6 version as I just learned about it's existence last night. I had a question and it may require some background from you to help educate me :) but know I really appreciate your time. As someone with minimal OSS time these days myself I understand the weight of each question/ PR/ issue.

I noticed the ES6 import statements in this project (the ES6 version) have a suffix/ or extension of `.js` but all other ES6 modules I look at in react/ ember / angular do not include this.

`import baseGetTag from './.internal/baseGetTag.js'

Any particular reason why this is the way it is today? Are you open to a PR/ or some modified build (publish?) step to truncate that `.js` extension (from import statements) ?

A little background for you - as I'm not just out here bike shedding believe it or not :)

I work primarily to widen the adoption of redux in the emberJS ecosystem. As part of this effort I author a number of shims required to make library XYZ ember-cli friendly. I was tackling the work required to compile the flow source for `redux-offline` / which then required a dependency shim for `redux-persist` - which later required a dependency shim for this library (lodash-es). My custom build takes the ES6 source and compiles it to named AMD (on the fly) for ember-cli compatibility. All good for everything up to this point ... until I looked at the AMD output and saw it was having a hard time with the `.js` extension (found in the import statements of lodash-es).

Example:

isPlainObject includes a requirement for baseGetTag (at the top by way of an [import](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/master/isPlainObject.js#L1))

`import baseGetTag from './.internal/baseGetTag.js'`

The compiled AMD looks like this (notice the trailing .js)

`define('lodash/isPlainObject', ['exports', 'lodash/_baseGetTag.js'`

Then, when I look at the baseGetTag definition ... to my surprise it looks like this

`define('lodash/_baseGetTag', ['exports'`

I could work around this/ or hack something but it got me asking if I was spending time on the right thing. As I don't see any other ES6 module using the `.js` extension for imports I wanted to ask if we could remove it or alter the build process that produces this to omit it.

Thoughts? Again - really appreciate this great community project!

title: Using Array.prototype.slice.call(array ...) instead of array.slice(...) may break reactivity in some frameworks
body:
Is there any reason to [use call here](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/master/.internal/basePullAt.js#L26) ?

I'm a [Vue](https://vuejs.org/) user, and Vue overrides `splice` method to make array properties reactive. 

So using this pattern in lodash sources breaks reactivity when using lodash in a Vue application, because it always use the default array slice method, instead of the overriden one.

Workaround is to use `_.find(...)` followed by a vanilla `Array.splice(...)`, instead of `_.remove(...)` for instance.

title: valueBy proposal
body:
There is a `keyBy` in `lodash` that allows to build an object base on array where objects keys are generated by the iterator. Proposal is to add paired to `keyBy` - `valueBy` function that will also traverse over the array but iterator would build values

Example:
```js
const names = ['Kate', 'Justin', 'Bob']
_.valueBy(names, name => `Hello ${name}`) 
```
Would output
```js
{
  Kate: 'Hello Kate', 
  Justin: 'Hello Justin', 
  Bob: 'Hello Bob'
}
```

title: Support caching inside _.template
body:
Abstract engine libraries such as [Consolidate](https://github.com/tj/consolidate.js/) support conventions for developers to specify whether or not to use caching for templates. Swig, though discontinued, has a fairly simple method of in-memory caching of compiled templates (see [here](https://github.com/paularmstrong/swig/blob/master/lib/swig.js#L200)). It should be a fairly low cost for the performance gains.

Apologies if this has already been listed as an issue before!

Not all of Backbone's Underscore-proxied methods are supported by Lodash 4
body:
Backbone provides proxies for some Underscore methods, such as `invoke` and `pick`. These methods have been changed in Lodash v4 to `invokeMap` and `pickBy` (when using an iteratee), but Backbone does not provide proxies to these new Lodash methods, it continues to proxy to the same methods, which is now incorrect. 

I've created two codepens with the same code, one with Underscore and one with Lodash 4. 

Underscore + Backbone:
http://codepen.io/anon/pen/ryKqXV?editors=0011

Lodash 4 + Backbone:
http://codepen.io/anon/pen/bqKmRL?editors=0011

You can clearly see that the Lodash codepen does not work with Backbone as expected. Note: Although I've only demonstrated a problem with `invoke` and `pick`, this same issue also exists with various other Underscore-proxied methods in Backbone. 

I understand that Backbone clearly defines Underscore as a dependency, so it's OK by me if Lodash doesn't work correctly with Backbone. However, I recommend either fixing these issues OR removing Backbone support from the Lodash documentation (such as: "Lodash works great with Backbone" on https://github.com/lodash/lodash/wiki/Migrating).

title: v4.14.2 has broken _.set behavior
_.template erroneously escapes HTML when called multiple times in quick succession
body:
When _.template function is called multiple times in quick succession it may fail to correctly process the argument string. Here is a [JS Fiddle](https://jsfiddle.net/cLfdog0u/3/) that illustrates the problem. **Expected result:** Text "SOME TEXT" in bold red Helvetica is displayed. The HTML shall look like this: `
SOME TEXT
` **Actual result:** Text `SOME TEXT` is displayed. The HTML looks like this: `
<span class="blah1 blah2 blah3">SOME TEXT</span>
` If you decrease MAX_CYCLES to 0 you will see the expected output. Note that MAX_CYCLES == 1000000 is a much exaggerated value. This issue was detected in an enterprise project where number of successive invocations required to reproduce it was around 2-digit number (on a developer's machine). I was able to reproduce it on JS Fiddle with a number of cycles around 10000.

title: .sort() on chaining crashes on IE
_.set updates old references
fp.get(obj, "someKey") always undefined
body:
My script `index.js`:
```javascript
"use strict";

var _ = require("lodash");
var fp = require("lodash/fp");

const obj = { apple: "tastes good", banana: "even better" };

console.log("begin tests");

console.log(_.get(obj, "apple")); // tastes good
console.log(_.get(obj, "banana")); // even better
console.log(_.get(obj, "pear")); // undefined

console.log(fp.get(obj, "apple")); // undefined
console.log(fp.get(obj, "banana")); // undefined
console.log(fp.get(obj, "pear")); // undefined
```

Prints:
```text
begin tests
tastes good
even better
undefined
undefined
undefined
undefined
```

my `package.json`:
```javascript
{
  "name": "lodash-fp-bug",
  "version": "1.0.0",
  "description": "",
  "main": "index.js",
  "scripts": {
    "test": "echo \"Error: no test specified\" && exit 1"
  },
  "keywords": [],

  "license": "ISC",
  "dependencies": {
    "lodash": "4.17.4"
  }
}
```

I ran `node index.js`. `node -v` returns `v7.6.0`

title: Support ES6 Map/Set in _.each?
Combine two objects based on the first one
group by null value coverts to "null" as a string
body:
lets say you have an array:

var x = [{id: null, value: "cat"}, { id: null, value: "dog"}]

now if you tried to group by the id which is null, the map function will convert the null to "null". I am trying to check for null keys to replace it with "No Data", but I do not want to write specific check for "null" if it is not original in the data. Is there a fix for this? Am I doing something wrong? 

It works fine if I do not have a map function, but with the map like below, it will replace the null with "null"

_.chain(x).groupBy("id").map((value, key) => {return { key: key, value: value} }).value()

title: _. sortedUniq returns undefined when used.
Lazy but finite reduce for recursive data structures and an unbounded number of reducers  (see comments)
body:
Good day everyone!

Over the past weeks we've been working with arbitrarily nested objects and arrays (mixed altogether), up until we've spotted the necessity of a recursive reduce function that could be used to transform, but at least to obtain, certain if not every property of this nested structure, which could also be stopped at any given point if a condition is sufficient. Essentially, we've been looking at what in haskell would be a `fold takeWhile`, but for deep/recursive objects/arrays.

After several iterations, the function valid for these use cases that we haven't been able to simplify anymore is the following:

```js
// Recursive fold takeWhile (like in haskell)
// fn is the iterator
// obj is the iteratee
// r is the accumulator
const foldWhile = (fn, obj, r = []) => {
  let innerFold = o => !(typeof o === 'object') ? o
    : Object.keys(o).every(k => fn(r, o[k], k) && innerFold(o[k]))
  innerFold(obj)
  return r
}
```

_**Note:** this is implemented with lodash in our code, but since it doesn't need lodash, I'm using generic es6 to show what it does._  
_**Note2:** Besides using functions from the Lodash ecosystem, this would benefit from a trampoline._

The main point of the function is combining the use of `every` recursively to stop at any point of the (_lazy_) evaluation of the nested object/array, with the use of an accumulator, which is handled to the user.

To see use cases and tests, see this gist: https://gist.github.com/sadasant/de106b879c61f21797dffdaa577f7868

We have been looking for opensource alternatives, but we haven't been successful.

I know that there have been several issues in this repo about lazy evaluation and nested data structures, however there doesn't seem to be an agreement on how to combine both the nested structures and the stopping of the fold at any given point.

Having that said,  
I wonder if this is interesting to anybody. We would definitely prefer using opensource instead of maintaining our own code.

Thank you for the time.

title: mutators should throw if object frozen
lowerCase replaces åäö with aao
body:
This seems to be a consistent issue with all casing functions using `createCompounder.js`.
Example:
```js
_.lowerCase('räven-åt-i-köket')
// returns 'raven at i koket'
```

However, when replicating the `lowerCase` function it returns the expected string:
```js
const reApos = /['\u2019]/g
const lc = (str) => _.reduce(
  _.words(_.toString(str).replace(reApos, '')),
  (result, word, index) => result + (index ? ' ' : '') + word.toLowerCase(),
  ''
)

lc('räven-åt-i-köket')
// returns 'räven åt i köket'

title: Need documentation clarification on replacing value of .cache property of memoized functions
_.reduce works incorrectly without accumulator
body:
_.reduce works incorrectly without accumulator
```
_.reduce({a: 1, b: 2}, (res, value, key) => value === 1 ? key : res)
```
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/593571/23892837/4f36a770-08ad-11e7-8263-2400f50724dd.png)

title: Fix trailing edge issue in throttle
body:
PR to address issue https://github.com/lodash/lodash/issues/3051

Note: Given the state of flux of the repo, I was unable to run any scripts or tests, except for some local tests. There are also not any tests here, since they don't seem to be in this repo? Please advise.

Eventually I determined that the issue boils down to a fundamental incompatibility between the expectations for `debounce` and the expectations for `throttle`. Following the trailing edge, `debounce` does not (and should not) care about the the amount of time elapsed before the next leading edge. `throttle` does. There seem to be three possible approaches to resolving this:

1. Decouple the `throttle` and `debounce` implementations again. No thanks.
1. Reclaim `maxWait` in the name of House Throttle. In the original debounce-based throttle implementation, setting `maxWait` reset the `lastCall` time to the time that the trailing edge created by `maxWait` was invoked (see [here](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/commit/1933a766310997518ab09f591cf364bd71d30607#diff-001d0647fb00f8336795faccdec19a31R4885). This is ostensibly not correct, which is probably why the behavior was changed at some point.
1. Add a new option that `throttle` can utilize. This is the approach I went with.

I added an option called `cooldown` which lets you specify the minimum amount of time that must elapse between a trailing edge and a leading edge. Calls to `debounced` that occur in that interval are deferred until the end of that cooldown period (effectively creating a new trailing edge).

title: Leaking global
body:
As described in https://github.com/webpack/webpack/issues/4465, lodash assigns itself to `window` when compiled using webpack.

While a workaround is to switch to `lodash-es` and alias `lodash`, IMHO this should fixed in lodash.

title: Throttle invokes leadingEdge immediately after trailingEdge
fp/gt, fp/lt... should flip their arguments
body:
I think the order should change in fp because as it is curried, it feels weird when you partially apply them:

```js
const isPositive = gt(0);
const isNegative = gt(0); // what ?

isPositive(2); // false <-- fails
isNegative(-2); // true <-- works but...
```

Other example with composition:

```js
const overlaps = x => compose(
  gt(0), // works if we use lt(0) but it seems weird when reading the code
  get('length'),
  intersection(castArray(x)),
  castArray
);

overlaps([1, 2])([2, 3]); // false --> should be true
overlaps(2)([2, 3]); // false --> should be true
```

Can test here: http://jsbin.com/kezohajujo/edit?js,console
